description.plain:
Pavement was an American indie rock and alternative rock band formed in Stockton, California in 1989. They are one of the most influential and important bands to emerge from the American underground in the 90’s and are considered to be one of the best bands of the decade.

Pavement lasted until 1999 when lead singer, guitarist and songwriter Stephen Malkmus got tired of touring and being in a rock band.
The classic formation consisted of Stephen Malkmus (lead vocals and guitar), Scott Kannberg (guitar and vocals), Mark Ibold (bass), Steve West (drums) and Bob Nastanovich (percussion and backing vocals).

They briefly reunited in 2010 and 2020 just to play shows.

songs.title: 5 - 4 = Unity

description.plain:
This is the only instrumental song in the album. The song features Jazz elements and a 5/4 meter thus the inclusion of numbers 5 and 4 in the title.

Also, the song is called 5-4=Unity, not 5+4=unity. This is because five minus four is one. 1=unity.

The song samples Dave Brubeck Quartet’s song Take Five.

songs.title: Ann Don’t Cry

description.plain:
“Ann Don’t Cry” is the 7th song featured on Pavement’s 1999 album Terror Twilight. Written by lead singer and guitarist, Stephen Malkmus.

The title introduces the character Ann, who is the subject of the song. The title suggests that the speaker and Ann have a strong connection, because the speaker cares enough to comfort her. The word cry suggests that Ann is facing a difficult challenge. The connotation of ‘cry’ is unclear here; it may refer to tears, a verbal outburst, or even anger. The meaning of cry is the key to understanding this song.

The first verse of the song has a different speaker than the rest.  It seems that the first verse is in Ann’s words, describing the other speaker.  She seems to view the speaker in a negative light saying things like “you never had a chance” and calling him a “cold, cold boy with American heart.”  Ann’s description seems to paint a picture of a man that lacks sensitivity.

The speaker responds with his own explanation.  He says “my heart is not a wide open thing,” and tells her “Don’t believe in what they say.”  This is the speakers attempt to clear his name, that his isn’t as cold as people might think, he just prefers to keep to himself.

songs.title: AT&T

description.plain:
“AT&T” is the 12th track off Pavement’s third album Wowee Zowee which was written by lead singer and guitarist Stephen Malkmus.

Wowee Zowee was the less successful follow up to their first two albums that brought them to fame. It significantly divided the fans they had obtained from Slanted and Enchanted (1992) and Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain (1994). This was due to the album’s experimental sound and lyrics that strayed from the more traditional rock sound of Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain. Thus the album is now considered a backlash against their new found fame as well as fear of the spectre of corporate control from major labels that would take hold on their music and lives. Rolling Stones stated in their review that Pavement was afraid of traditional mainstream success. And though the album crashed commercially it further cemented Pavement’s status as critical darlings of the indie music world.

Since Wowee Zowee is known for having a very eclectic sound compared to Pavement’s prior albums (which Malkmus has admitted was due to excessive marijuana use). Malkmus uses spoken word as much as rhythmic singing. Traditional rock instruments are backed up by less common instruments such as cellos, harmonicas, and synthesizers. Also of note is the use of heavy distortion of both the guitars and Malkmus' singing.

The song itself uses a more traditional rock sound and instrumentation except for a small part near the end that utilizes the distortion so common in the album’s other songs combined with an “echo” effect of Malkmus speaking in the background while stating “Levi, Guess” repeatedly.

The song is named after large-scale phone and telecommunications company AT&T. AT&T, as well as being a large and imposing corporate entity, also metaphorically represents communication between individuals within society, commercialization of non-face-to-face interaction, and overall corporate control of the aspects of human life. It also establishes a connection with New York City which is where AT&T is based.

songs.title: Best Friends Arm

description.plain:
Stephen Malkmus' jarring take on adulthood, where he desperately longs to return to the innocence of those childhood, best friend, embraces.
A bitter look at the distance that develops between friends in middle-age, and a question as to why the fuck we spend all our adult lives working.

songs.title: Black Out

description.plain:
“Black Out” is the third track on Pavement’s third album Wowee Zowee (1995).

A wide variety of connotations exist for this title. For instance, a popular way of describing a power outage inside a building or area is referred to as a black out. Also, overindulging in alcohol can lead to a memory loss known as being black out drunk. Or in the military, a commo black out refers to the halting of communication devices in order to prevent sensitive information from being released.

Although used in several varying circumstances, the term “black-out” retains a similar meaning no matter how it is applied: an absence of something that is expected to be present.

In the context of this song, black out seems to refer to the lack of joy or contentment that Malkmus finds in his own life. Wowee Zowee as a whole is thought to be the band’s reaction to the moderate success of their first two albums. As a Rolling Stone article in 1998 put it after “Wowee Zowee was released, "What does a defiantly anti-corporate rock band do when it starts getting too much attention? In Pavement’s case, they recoil.” Perhaps finally making it big wasn’t what it was cracked up to be leading to a feeling of emptiness even greater than before.

songs.title: Box Elder

description.plain: One of the first songs in the Pavement canon and a rare one at that – the riff was generated by Spiral Stairs and the lyrics were added after the fact by Stephen Malkmus. A more collaborative effort than almost anything that followed.

songs.title: Carrot Rope

description.plain: Written to trip up anyone trying to over analyze Pavement lyrics, (ahem), “Carrot Rope” is the final song on Terror Twilight. It is stylized as “…and Carrot Rope” on the back of the album. Despite its success on the UK Singles Chart, the song wasn’t put on Quarantine the Past: The Best of Pavement.

songs.title: Chesley’s Little Wrists

description.plain:
Track #7 on Pavement’s debut LP Slanted and Enchanted.
On an album adored for its unconventional takes on pop, surf-pop and garage, ‘Chesley’s Little Wrists’ is an extremist outlier: it starts at whacky and stays there for the duration of its out-of-tune, off-tempo 75 seconds. Although vocalist Stephen Malkmus gibbers and stops-starts many words, the only legible phrase is “I’m bogged down.”

songs.title: Conduit for Sale!

description.plain:
Malkmus excitedly tells a story of a rich man who inherits valuable land that is well kept and nice for those in the settlement to live.  He turns it to shit to try to save money, and everyone become unhappy. Having run it into the ground, he tries to sell it but can’t find takers, so to save face and look like a selfless philanthropist, he gives it away to those who live there.

Worth noting, the structure and tone of ‘Conduit for Sale’ bear a strong resemblance to the song ‘New Face in Hell’ by The Fall.



A fan theory states that this song references the House of Savoy, the final Italian royal family to rule before Italy became a republic after the end of World War II.

Herr Proctor, in this case, may represent Umberto II, the last king of Italy. Umberto was named king when his father, Victor Emmanuel III, abdicated his throne and fled into exile. Umberto ruled for only 34 days, during which the monarchy he was meant to save fell apart. A public vote was held to transition Italy from a monarchy into a republic, the passing of which saw Umberto accept deposition and flee the country just as his father had. The end of Umberto’s rule marked the official end of the Savoy monarchy.

The line in the song referencing “Torino boys” supports this theory – Torino is the Italian name for Turin, the capital city of the Italian Piedmont region. The “conduit” itself may represent the Turin-Modane railway. Connecting Italy to France, the railway is a section of the Victor Emmanuel Railway, named for Victor Emmanuel II, the grandfather of Victor Emmanuel III. The reference to “an Italian male” also supports this.

There may also be a connection to the song Embassy Row on Pavement’s later album Brighten the Corners. Embassy Row’s lyrics deal with foreign diplomacy and a coup d'etat, such as the 25 Luglio coup orchestrated by Victor Emmanuel III against the Italian prime minister and fascist dictator Benito Mussolini.

songs.title: Cream of Gold

description.plain:
The song “Cream of Gold” was released in Pavement’s album Terror Twilight in 1999. The title of the song is much softer and brighter than many of the others on this album, which have a bitter and grungy interpretation, such as “Spit on a Stranger” or “The Hexx”. The 1990’s was known for the popularity of “grunge” rock music and alternative or indie sound. According to The Quietus.com, a British online rock music culture magazine, the song “Cream of Gold” allowed Pavement (an indie rock band) to “rock out and still retain their indie-cred”. It provided a hint of the popular style of music that many brooding teens clad in flannel shirts and dark wash jeans could relate to and embodied the spirit of the “outcast” sound that many teens found appealing.

“Cream of Gold” has the conventional grungy sound that is attributed to Pavement. The way Steven Malkmus bitingly sings his bitterness parallels the harsh lyrics.

The title “Cream of Gold” has a luxurious connotation. “Cream” is a word for an expensive ointment, and “gold” is a precious metal, so a cream of gold would be the ultimate luxury. It would only be available to those of high class because they are the only ones who can afford it.
Although a cream of gold has only a limited amount of people have access to such a high-end product, the bitter feeling after having someone you trusted and loved destroy you–the subject of “Cream of Gold”–is a feeling accessible, unfortunately, to all.
Another interpretation of the title “Cream of Gold” focuses on the ointment aspect of the word “cream”. An ointment is primarily a soother of irritations. “Gold” also indicates the best standard of something. So a cream of gold is the ultimate soother.
The title seems to be the cream of gold for the song–soothing words that ease the harsh language and feeling that constitutes the lyrics.

songs.title: Date with IKEA

description.plain:
“Date with Ikea” is the fourth track on Pavement’s 1997 album Brighten the Corners.

Pavement formed as a band in 1989, releasing their first album on the market in 1992. Their album Brighten the Corners, released in 1997, came around the peak for alternative rock as a musical genre. With this album , Pavement attempted to achieve a more mainstream, classic rock feel to contrast their more controversial album, Wowee Zowee, which generated hostility at the 1995 Lollapallooza festival.

Ikea is a Swedish furniture and home decor retailer. The store’s popularity stems from its unique approach to furniture retail in that full assembly of each piece is required. The cost of furniture is thus reduced since the additional steps of assembly are left to the consumer.

The first word of the title, “Date,” can imply various meanings: an appointment, a romantic encounter, a day on the calendar, etc. The ambiguity of the word “date” is then relatively defined by the word “with.” Had this been a date “to” Ikea, the “date” would be interpreted as an appointment. However, because the word is “with,”  Ikea becomes personified, implying a level of romanticism. This phrasing demonstrates a connection with the store and the unknown narrator, although this relationship is, thus far, undefined.

The song is heavily distorted and is both sung and played in a higher range, similar to the rest of the album. Unlike the rest of the album it is characterized by an upbeat tempo and the use of major chords, which give it a happy sound. It fades in, and then progresses to a steady beat and uses both lyrical and instrumental repetition. There is a fifteen-second bridge in the last minute of the song, which is followed by another choral repetition. The music then comes to a sudden stop, leaving the distortion to fade out on its own.

songs.title: Elevate Me Later

description.plain:
“Elevate Me Later” is Pavement’s second song on the album Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain written by Stephen Malkmus.

The title complements the song’s critique of society’s typical upper class by dismissing personal economic “elevation” for a “later” time. The song’s topic of economic disparity is recognized by the imagery approached throughout the song. In the first verse circumstances associated with lower class individuals and those in poverty are described; in the second, the topics approached are associated with wealth and economic prestige. Malkmus identifies with the individuals described in the first verse, and separates himself from those of the second.
Ultimately, “Elevate Me Later” is an excellent complement to the album, Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain. The inequality of economic success will always find the label of “Crookedness”.

songs.title: Embassy Row

description.plain:
“Embassy Row” is the seventh track on Pavement’s Brighten the Corners, an album released in 1997. It was written by lead vocalist Stephen Malkmus.

The song’s title, “Embassy Row,” brings the image of international affairs to the forefront of our minds. It talks about a place, a row of embassies where foreign nations come together. It also brings forth an image of a certain type of person – a suave and cultured individual.Of course, diplomats are, first and foremost, representatives. They take the part of a country’s voice in a foreign land, and, by extension, all that country’s citizens. This establishes the idea of representation and, as per usual, bad representation (no one has ever written a song called “My Senator/ Representative/Diplomat is So Awesome!”).

The song has been described as having a more “rock” feel than the rest of the album. This could be because the subject matter of the song (which is about politics) lends itself to that. Politics and corruption are common themes in punk rock.

songs.full_title: Father to a Sister of Thought by Pavement
songs.title: Father to a Sister of Thought
songs.title_with_featured: Father to a Sister of Thought

description.plain:
“Father to a Sister of Thought”, written by Stephen Malkmus, was released in 1995 on Pavement’s third album, Wowee Zowee.

This particular song by Pavement focuses on the image of two relationships: one being between a “Father” and a “Sister of Thought”, and the other between a sister and a thought. The first relationship could be religious (Priest and nun), familial, or of Creator (God); however, the relationship is not clear cut because the band did not use father and daughter as a comparison. The relationship of the sister and thought depends on how thought is interpreted. Thought could be either an adjective, describing the sister, or a noun, as a separate entity of the sister yet still related.

The song is noticeably different in sound from other songs by Pavement, and Wowee Zowee in particular. Generally working within alternative rock, Pavement took a different direction with Father to a Sister of Thought, utilizing a more “jangly” sounding guitar, and leaning closer to alternative country than anything else. Although the sound itself was atypical, the concept of experimentation isn’t foreign on Wowee Zowee: Pitchfork described it as “Pavement’s White Album,” (a reference to the equally eccentric self-titled Beatles album, whose all white cover gave it its nickname) because it’s “a little bit of everything thrown together.”

songs.title: Fillmore Jive

description.plain:
The epic seven minute closer to Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain about disillusionment at the end of “the rock n' roll era” and the current music scene.

Its unconventional structure is loose and doesn’t follow typical verses, choruses, and bridges. Instead, it is a jam-sesh burst of ideas intermixed with guitar solos, which may seem disorganized at first glance, but contain a deep grasp of the era it came from and the message it wants to send to the listeners.

Half of its title comes from The Fillmore, a famous historic concert hall in San Francisco, is home to the psychedelic movement of the sixties and seventies and the rock revolution of the 80s. The Who, Pink Floyd, and the Grateful Dead are among the many bands who played there and helped shape Pavements sophomore album. The reference to Fillmore in the title “Fillmore Jive” is a response to the the death of the eighties rock era and the birth of the nineties punk movement.

The other half, “jive” is a contrast to the song itself. It’s an anachronism, both in style and feeling, coming from the twenties era as a style of dance, it evolved into forties slang referring to the foolishness of a thought or object.  In the context of the song, jive is used as a juxtaposition to the intensity of the content of the song highlighting the foolishness of what rock and roll has become in the eyes of Pavement.

Ironically, the band never got to play at the Fillmore, they played at the Great American Music Hall in San Francisco a mere ten days before the Fillmore was set to reopen. None other than Smashing Pumpkins, a band criticized earlier on the album, was the headliner for the inaugural night at the Fillmore. This controversy reaffirmed the bands belief in going against the grain, Scott Kannberg, guitarist, shouted “Fuck the Fillmore!” during the band’s final set. The sentiment is further intensified by “Fillmore Jive” itself, seeing that the song is about the intrusion of punk music  in the era of rock and roll. Some interpret “Fillmore Jive” as a eulogy written for the death of rock and roll music, because there is a sense of respect while bidding farewell to the 80s rock era; however, if Pavement would have known about the betrayal that came from the very subject of their ode, they perhaps would not have written the song in the first place.

songs.title: Frontwards

description.plain: SM: “‘Frontwards’ is kind of wistfully thinking about 1977 and ‘78, and being there in Stockton. People just starting to smoke, and chicks with those combs and feathered hair and those tight jeans that make camel toes, and migrants, farm workers and stuff. To me, it’s evocative of that. I can really see those images in my mind. And the chord changes are real basic. Oasis could have used those chords, as far as I’m concerned. They’re that good.”

songs.full_title: Give It a Day by Pavement
songs.title: Give It a Day

description.plain:
This song appeared on the Pacific Trim EP in 1996.

The lyrics concern religious extremism, sexism, and the Puritan legacy in America, reflecting Stephen Malkmus’s interest in history, which he studied at the University of Virginia.

The lyrics concern religious extremism, sexism, and the Puritan legacy in America, reflecting Stephen Malkmus’s interest in history, which he studied at the University of Virginia.

songs.lyrics:
Increase Mather told her daddy
"I roundly disagree with you
Your vocal style's too preachy
All the yokels mock your teaching."
But Cotton, he was just oblivious
To all their cutting pleas
Soon the townfolk took to it
In every pew they looked to him
For guidance just like eyeless lambs
Awaiting that ol' kabob stand
The skeptics formed
The nation's born
They want to have it, Cotton's dream
But Increase had them mounted
And they burned on open fires
So the word spread just like smallpox
In the Sudan

The gentry cried:
"Give it a day!"
"Give it a day!"
"Give it a day!"

"Give it a day!"
"Give it a day!"
"Give it a day!"
Years and years have passed
Since the Puritans invaded our soul
Just like those Arab terrorists
You'll never know
But today the gods can't make us quake
We see our lives as situations
Eyes are eyes and teeth are teeth
Well mine are rotten underneath
I got two ways we can separate from the clan

If I could fly, I could fry

I hope you profited from this bulletin
And it stabilized your land
You're drenched, you're fired
(You gentrified?)
Your Alzheim clan, but
Your father is another one of them
I don't want to mention him again, cause
I talked to him last night
He hates my guts
We had a fight
And he called you a slut girl
Why's that?
What did you do to him to make him think1EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.title: Gold Soundz

description.plain:
“Gold Soundz” was voted the best song of the 90s by Pitchfork, a seminal indie online magazine. The song deals with the loss of love in the midst of a breakup.

In Stephen Malkmus' track notes for the re-release of “Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain” he describes the track simply as “Gold Soundz – a self doubt song”.

songs.title: Grave Architecture

description.plain:
“Grave Architecture” is the 11th track on the album Wowee Zowee released in 1995 by Pavement. The album was a departure from the more traditional and commercially successful Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain in favor of a more cluttered and experimental sound. Really, the song isn’t extraordinarily remarkable on its own in the album. It’s more of the “meat” of the album; located near the middle, its surreal, cryptic lyrics and steadily deteriorating instrumental track embody the sound of the album.

The title of this song can be interpreted multiple ways. The word “grave” contains ambiguity in that it can either be a noun (where someone is interred) or an adjective (denoting seriousness or sullenness). “Architecture” can refer to both the concrete “monuments” to the deceased and to abstract societal structures. One such abstract architecture is that of urban society, a major theme of the song and perhaps one that is personally relevant to Malkmus who grew up in Stockton, a city near San Francisco and the location of a 1989 school shooting.

With this ambiguity in mind, the song still definitely has an over-arching morbidity to it. This morbidity is in stark contrast with the instrumentals, which feature catchy bass licks and plucky, almost Hawaiian-style guitar overlays (though it tends toward more distortion near the end). Malkmus plays on the dissonance between the lyrics and the instruments to feed into the discord that drives the whole album.

songs.title: Harness Your Hopes

description.plain:
“Harness Your Hopes” was originally an incredibly obscure B-side by the band present on the Spit on a Stranger single quietly released in 1999. It was also released as a separate single in France.

For a long time the song was largely unknown to most except the most seasoned Pavement fans, to the point where frontman Stephen Malkmus did not even recognise the song when he heard it played in a bakery. Upon Spotify rolling out its “autoplay” feature in 2017, the song quickly became the band’s most popular on streaming services for no discernable reason, and became popular as a song on TikTok.

songs.full_title: Heaven Is a Truck by Pavement
songs.title: Heaven Is a Truck

description.plain:
The song title objectifies an abstract idea of Heaven, an ideal thing that everyone wants, and makes it into something concrete and attainable. Heaven is generally associated with positive things and sayings, such as “that was heavenly” or “heaven in a cup”, to describe an object like coffee or food. Heaven is declared to be a truck which makes this abstract idea seem like an attainable, strong and powerful object that can be bought. Trucks are generally thought to be the largest vehicles on the road with more power than other cars; it makes Heaven seem just as powerful and large.

“Heaven Is a Truck” sounds drastically different from Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain’s other songs. This song has a more mellow tone and utilizes heavy amounts of piano where piano is almost nonexistent on the other tracks.

songs.full_title: Hit the Plane Down by Pavement
songs.title: Hit the Plane Down

description.plain:
The title, “Hit the Plane Down”, invokes a vivid image. The image in the listener’s mind connotes anger and death. The phrase could be a command, with the singer ordering someone to destroy the plane. It is unknown whether the plane is literal or figurative-it may just be a metaphor for destructive behavior.
The majority of Pavement’s material was written by front-man Stephen Malkmus. Guitarist and background vocalist Scott Kannberg penned “Hit the Plane Down”, also performing lead vocals. This led to the altered instrumentation and tone of the song.

As mentioned previously, this song is instrumentally different from the other songs on the album. The heavy use of bass guitar gives the song a darker, moodier feel than those also on the album. Kannberg’s voice is distorted somewhat adding to that darker theme of the song.

The song “Hit the Plane Down” alludes to drugs and the powers they possess. However, based on the band’s stance on drugs, it could be implied that the drugs are an extended metaphor for 90s rock culture. In this song, drugs are personified in order to show the devastation a they can wreak on a society – taking control of the scene. This could be directly related to the power major labels had over bands during the 90s. Major record labels had control of image, tour schedules, and even the sound of bands – they made every decision for the band. Similarly, a person under the influence of drugs is unable to make decisions – the drugs make all the decisions.

The use of the metaphor implies Pavement’s stand on both 90s rock culture, as well as drugs themselves. Both are painted in a negative light – as resolute powers that are a force to be reckoned with.

The majority of Pavement’s material was written by front-man Stephen Malkmus. Guitarist and background vocalist Scott Kannberg penned “Hit the Plane Down”, also performing lead vocals. This led to the altered instrumentation and tone of the song.

As mentioned previously, this song is instrumentally different from the other songs on the album. The heavy use of bass guitar gives the song a darker, moodier feel than those also on the album. Kannberg’s voice is distorted somewhat adding to that darker theme of the song.

The song “Hit the Plane Down” alludes to drugs and the powers they possess. However, based on the band’s stance on drugs, it could be implied that the drugs are an extended metaphor for 90s rock culture. In this song, drugs are personified in order to show the devastation a they can wreak on a society – taking control of the scene. This could be directly related to the power major labels had over bands during the 90s. Major record labels had control of image, tour schedules, and even the sound of bands – they made every decision for the band. Similarly, a person under the influence of drugs is unable to make decisions – the drugs make all the decisions.

The use of the metaphor implies Pavement’s stand on both 90s rock culture, as well as drugs themselves. Both are painted in a negative light – as resolute powers that are a force to be reckoned with.

songs.title: Kennel District

description.plain:
Kennel District appears on Pavement’s 1995 album Wowee Zowee.

It is one of only a handful of songs in Pavement’s discography that is written and sung by Scott Kannberg, rather than Stephen Malkmus.

An older version of Kennel District with different lyrics was recorded during the session for Pavement’s prior album, Crooked Rain Crooked Rain and released on that album’s 2004 re-release.

songs.title: Major Leagues

description.plain:
“Major Leagues” is the fourth track on the band’s final album, Terror Twilight, released in 1999. It differs from other songs on the Terror Twilight album, however, in its sound and style. “Major Leagues” is described as one of Pavement’s “softest, most sentimental songs to date”. While the album as a whole is considered to be part of the Indie Rock/Alternative genre, “Major Leagues” in particular is described as a “dreamy country-rock ballad”. It is a lyrical song that has a unique sound, including edgy vocals and harmonious instrumentals.

The title “Major Leagues” has a fairly ambiguous interpretation. Initially, the title of this song invokes the image of an elite group, which is commonly associated with Major League Baseball. This association raises the question of what the speaker’s relationship to the “major leagues” is. It could either be a reference to the speaker’s belonging in the “major leagues” or his desire to transition into a higher standing. The word “leagues”, however, could also signify a great distance. This distance could be representative of either an emotional or a physical separation.

When the lyrics are analyzed, “Major Leagues” seems to serve as a representation of a struggling relationship. There is a speaker who is making a last attempt to stay with his partner, yet there is clear doubt in the lyrics that the relationship will find success. They are dreaming about advancing to the “major leagues,” a higher level within their relationship; However, the descriptions of their current situation make this seem like an unrealistic goal. At many points in the song, it seems as though the relationship is one-sided and there is not a conscious effort being made by both individuals in the relationship to make it work.

songs.title: Motion Suggests

description.plain:
(Gio)
Motion Suggests” is the 7th Track on Pavement’s 3rd Album, Wowee Zowee which was recorded in Easley County Jail in Memphis and released in 1995.

The “motion” in the title could signify, not only movement, but the description of a movement since motion is a noun describing a verb. The vagueness of the “motion” is abetted by the lack of adjectives preceding the title, which leaves the specific “motion” open to interpretation. Is the motion ongoing and perpetual? Who is performing the “motion”? Is the “motion” aimed at someone or something? We would hope that the lyrics of the song would hint at the author’s intended meaning of “motion”. Sadly, we are never explicitly told what the author means through the lyrics.
“Motion Suggests” is unlike other songs in Pavement’s Wowee Zowee album as the lyrics don’t follow a coherent plot containing distinct events. As an audience, we are removed from the confines of a plot-driven narrative and placed in a scene imagined by Malkmus himself. As we listen, Stephen Malkmus takes us on a journey to his past in the first verse. His thoughts dramatically shift in the second verse as the audience experiences Malkmus’ strange sensual illusions concluded by his vague plans about his own future.
Overall, this song feels like a metaphorical monologue of Malkmus’ personal history followed by thoughts about his future. His lyrics suggest a journey scattered with drug use, heart break, euphoric highs, and gripping lows.

Sources:
Matador Records
Domino Records
Pavement 120 Minutes Interview
Pavement Interview
Pavement Reunion reported in Rolling Stone
Pavement Biography from Rolling Stone

songs.title: Newark Wilder

description.plain: The song title, “Newark Wilder,” evokes the idea of a place that lacks civilized behavior. Pavement recorded Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain in New York City, which is only 30 minutes away from Newark, New Jersey . As Mark Ibold, the band’s bassist, told Vice Magazine, the song was “pretty of-the-moment, provoked by the latest wilding incidents involving gangs in New York City and New Jersey.” The song utilizes “wilder” in its title to intensify how unrestrained the city’s inhabitants are, which is clearly demonstrated by its violent crime rate being triple the U.S. average.

songs.title: No More Kings

description.plain:
Pavement’s Schoolhouse Rock Rocks! contribution, a cover of the original Schoolhouse Rocks’s No More Kings turning the Revolutionary War history lesson into a Pavement-style declaration of independence and angst.

Fun fact: Stephen Malkmus was a history major and is known for including several historical references in his music, making this an appropriate fit.

songs.title: Old to Begin

description.plain:
Pavement’s “Old to Begin”, the fifth track off their 1997 album Brighten the Corners, is a relatively slow and quiet number, wedged alongside the similarly laid-back “Type Slowly” between the louder, more aggro-pop tracks of “Date w/ IKEA” and “Embassy Row”.

While singer-songwriter Stephen Malkmus still proves himself a “mountain of great complexity” with his obscurantist witticisms, there appears to be a pattern of meaning amidst the labyrinth of words, which, along with the jazzy mood, plodding riffs, the effortlessly lazy guitar solo, and of course the title, seems to portray the decay of man and his faculties through time, along with his petulant refusal to change for the better.

songs.title: Passat Dream

description.plain:
“Passat Dream”, the 10th track off of Pavement’s 1997 album. “Passat Dream”, along with “Date with IKEA”, is one of the two songs off Brighten the corners not written by Stephen Malkmus, the lead singer of the band. But instead, is written by another founding member, guitarist Scott Kannberg.

The song is a one-sided conversation between a buyer and a seller. In it the seller is trying to sell off a Volkswagen Passat, an economical family sedan, to a woman by telling her the purchase will bring her the happiness of a husband.

The song opens with an upbeat percussion and some synthesized sound effects, before the catchy guitar enters. The vocals are introduced with some looping “oohs,” repeated during the chorus. The song maintains an upbeat tempo, and a catchy melody with the guitar. The tone of the song is not interrupted by a slower or more mellow section, which contributes to the overall message of the song; that is, not deep or serious.

songs.title: Platform Blues

description.plain:
“Platform Blues” is the 6th song on Pavement’s 1999 album Terror Twilight; it is written by the lead singer of the band, Stephen Malkmus. Terror Twilight is the fifth and final album that the band released together before breaking up. The album received positive reviews and is described by Rolling Stone as having a dreamier and more romantic sound than their previous records.

The title suggests an emotional state relating to a physical place. The word “platform” could be a physical place like a stage, pedestal, or train platform. It could also be a metaphorical platform, raising the person up above others in some way. The word “blues” conveys the idea of sadness or discontent associated with this platform.

The song is in keeping with the musical styling of the rest of the songs on the album: the verses are slow and mellow, while the breaks have a faster and more upbeat sound.

“Platform Blues” is a criticism of the attitude many people have towards other people in places in life; that is to say, an attitude of voyeurism, where people find enjoyment is viewing the lives and even the suffering of others, but do not actually get involved in said lives.

songs.title: Range Life

description.plain:
“Range Life” is Pavement’s third single for Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain, the album that was a commercial and critical breakthrough for them.

Given a freewheeling, breezy country-folk sound, “Range Life” yearns for the simpler, “arranged” lifestyle, beyond the messy, disorganised kind of life that carefree teenagers live. It, essentially, marks the peripeteia in the bildungsroman of any fiery and rebellious adolescent into a mature adult.

This song had attracted controversy for its third verse, which labels the Smashing Pumpkins as “nature kids” and having “no function.”  A rumor soon surfaced that Billy Corgan had kicked Pavement out of Lollapalooza.  Corgan responded to the accusation in a 1995 interview with Rolling Stone:

I had no problem with Pavement. When I met the guys from Nick Cave’s band, they said they were told that I’d tried to kick them off the bill, too. I’m totally a Nick Cave fan. That was astounding to me, maybe Pavement didn’t start the rumor. Maybe it was some industry insider.

songs.full_title: Rattled by the Rush by Pavement
songs.title: Rattled by the Rush

description.plain:
“Rattled by the Rush” is the second track on Pavement’s album Wowee Zowee, and the album’s first single. Released in 1995, Rolling Stones calls it Pavement’s reaction to the fame they gained from Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain, which was never their intent. Although a short portion of this song can be heard in the cutscene music in the television show Friends, it is more famous for MTV’s banning of its music video, in which the camera work was deemed to make people too dizzy after appearing on MTV’s 120 Minutes. A secondary music video featuring parts of the original footage playing on a bathroom tile, with less spinning cameras, was released.

When looking at the title of this song it is immediately evident that the words “Rattled” and “Rush” both have negative connotations. The preposition “by” also gives causality to why the author says they are rattled. The word “Rush” usually refers to when a person is in a hurry or when a mob of people are all moving quickly toward something. Regardless, one typically rushes in a frantic manner, which usually paints a negative picture. Another way that one can feel a rush is the intense flooding of emotion that would come after a certain act such as, skydiving, riding a roller coaster, or anything of that nature. The word “Rattled” could refer to being either disturbed, rattled, or unnerved, which would be the emotional way to look at that. When looking at the physical definition of rattled, it could be referring to shaking a musical instrument or a small child’s toy. The title is emotional and it gives the listener the sense that something is coming at them and it can’t be stopped.

songs.full_title: Shady Lane/J vs. S by Pavement
songs.title: Shady Lane/J vs. S

description.plain:
Shady Lane is a single from Pavement’s fourth studio album Brighten the Corners released in 1997. The single was the most popular in the UK, reaching the top 40 list.

The title, “Shady Lane,” indicates a place with a distinct image associated with it. Shady, in the literal sense, offers protection from the sun/light. In this way, shady connotes peace and serenity as when you are sitting under a tree on a sunny day. Lane evokes the image of a pathway, anywhere from a serene trail to a street in a residential neighborhood.

The song focuses on money and its effect on relationships between different social classes. The story in the song revolves around a blind date between a higher class woman and presumably low class man.

This song is rather upbeat compared to the majority of the songs on the album. The beat of the song reflects the desire of finding that happy, shady lane.

songs.title: Silence Kid

description.plain:
“Silence Kid” is a label for the main character of Crooked Rain, Crooked Rain’s opening track. The  eponymous kid is characterized throughout the song as jaded and filtered; they are encouraged to change to be more open.

This song starts with a random conglomeration of noises, but then progresses to a steady rock song, a fitting representation of the 90s alternative rock genre.

And that’s right, it is “Silence Kid”, not the erroneous “Silence Kit” that was on the original backside artwork. Though the mistake was so widespread that it even occasionally shows up on set lists.
